message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and the presence of elevated 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospinal fluid further supports this diagnosis. The most likely finding on autopsy is spongiform vacuolation of the cortex. Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington's disease, focal inflammatory demyelination and gliosis is seen in multiple sclerosis, and deposits of amyloid beta peptides are seen in Alzheimer's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and elevated concentration of 14-3-3 protein suggest Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a prion disease. The most likely finding on autopsy is spongiform vacuolation of the cortex. None of the other options are usually associated with this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the given symptoms, the patient likely has Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a rare degenerative brain disorder caused by abnormal proteins called prions. The presence of 14-3-3 protein in the CSF is a diagnostic marker for CJD. Pathologic examination of the brain on autopsy will show spongiform vacuolation of the cortex, a characteristic finding in CJD. The other options are not associated with CJD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and elevated 14-3-3 protein in cerebrospinal fluid suggest the patient is suffering from Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). The most likely pathological finding in CJD is spongiform vacuolation of the cortex. Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington disease, focal inflammatory demyelination and gliosis is seen in multiple sclerosis, and deposits of amyloid beta peptides are seen in Alzheimer disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), and the elevated 14-3-3 protein in cerebrospinal fluid is a diagnostic marker for CJD. Spongiform vacuolation of the cortex is a characteristic finding on pathological examination of the brain in patients with CJD. Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington’s disease, while deposits of amyloid beta peptides are seen in Alzheimer’s disease. Focal inflammatory demyelination and gliosis are seen in multiple sclerosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and elevated concentration of 14-3-3 protein suggest Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), which is characterized by spongiform vacuolation of the cortex on pathologic examination of the brain on autopsy. Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington’s disease. Focal inflammatory demyelination and gliosis is characteristic of multiple sclerosis. Deposits of amyloid beta peptides are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.

The diffuse involuntary muscle jerking and elevated 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospinal fluid suggest Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), which is characterized by spongiform vacuolation of the cortex on brain autopsy. Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen are seen in Huntington’s disease, focal inflammatory demyelination and gliosis are seen in multiple sclerosis, and deposits of amyloid beta peptides are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the symptoms suggests Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), which is characterized by diffuse involuntary muscle jerking and elevated 14-3-3 protein concentration in cerebrospinal fluid. The most likely pathology findings for CJD are spongiform vacuolation of the cortex. Option A is more indicative of Huntington's disease, option B suggests multiple sclerosis, and option C suggests Alzheimer's disease.

The most likely pathological finding in CJD is spongiform vacuolation of the cortex. Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington's disease, focal inflammatory demyelination and gliosis is seen in multiple sclerosis, and deposits of amyloid beta peptides are seen in Alzheimer's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) and the elevated 14-3-3 protein in cerebrospinal fluid is a supportive laboratory test. Pathological examination of the brain in CJD typically shows spongiform vacuolation of the cortex, making answer choice (D) the correct option. Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington’s disease, focal inflammatory demyelination and gliosis are seen in multiple sclerosis, and deposits of amyloid beta peptides are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.
